instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.26V
threads.message:
Hello everybody !

The charger is stuck at 5V - 0amps.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> gets dragged down to 2.26v for an unknow reason. If I remove the resistor <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>, pin 1 gives me 3.4v. Resistance in diode mode (red probe on ground) on pin 2 is 0.395 and another way (black probe on ground) is 0.822

I've tried voltage injection, but it's not drawing any current. 

Any idea ,what's going on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.26V
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground around <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Start with their LDOs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.26V
threads.message:
Thank you for your answer!
Which LDOs do you mean ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.26V
threads.message:
Look at pages 29/30 in schematic.
I'm pretty sure you will find some lines with "LDO" in their names...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.26V
threads.message:
Thank you! I was. So
I don't have <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> for both ports and strange with <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>
I have got <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> is 2.2v and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> is 3.3v for one port 
And  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> is 3.3v and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> is 2.2v for another

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.26V
threads.message:
"Check diode mode to ground..."
Pay atention when read the posts.

BTW, 1V1 LDO voltage should appear only on the powered port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.26V
threads.message:
sorry for my stooped question ðŸ™ˆI have compered main lines with another board and nothing difference ....
any idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.26V
threads.message:
Then the low reading on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> should be caused by other chip, not <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.
That will be more dificult to locate...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.26V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.26V
threads.message:
Inject 3.5V and use thermal camera.
May need to wait several minutes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.26V
threads.message:
Just 11 mA if I inject 3.4v on L6995 and nothing ....
Cant see any hot in thermal camera of cause

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.26V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at 2.26V
threads.message:
I did it before, it was the same.
Now i inject with <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>
